review.title: Priv'IT: Private and Sample Efficient Identity Testing
review.abstract: We develop differentially private hypothesis testing methods for the small sample regime. Given a sample $\cal D$ from a categorical distribution $p$ over some domain $\Sigma$, an explicitly described distribution $q$ over $\Sigma$, some privacy parameter $\varepsilon$, accuracy parameter $\alpha$, and requirements $\beta_{\rm I}$ and $\beta_{\rm II}$ for the type I and type II errors of our test, the goal is to distinguish between $p=q$ and $d_{\rm{TV}}(p,q) \geq \alpha$.

metadata.title: Priv’IT: Private and Sample Efficient Identity Testing

sections.text: We provide theoretical limits for sample size, so that our method fulfils both the (ε, 0) differential privacy and guarantees βI and βII type I and type II errors. We show that differential privacy can be free in some parameter systems, and we always beat the sample complexity resulting from performing the χ2 test with loud counts or standard approaches such as repetitions to equip non-private statistics in the style of χ2 with differential privacy guarantees. We experimentally compare the sample complexity of our method with the recently proposed methods for private hypotheses testing [GLRV16, KR17].

sections.heading: 1 Introduction
sections.text: The hypothesis is the age-old problem of deciding whether observations of an unknown phenomenon p conform to a data protection model q. Frequently, p can be considered a distribution via an alphabet Σ, and the goal is to determine from samples from p whether it corresponds to any model distribution q or not. This type of test is the lifeblood of the scientific method and has received enormous studies in statistics since its inception, with the focus, of course, on minimizing the number of observations from the unknown distribution that are necessary to determine with confidence whether p = q or p = q.However, in several areas of research and application, sensitive information about individuals may be contained; consider, for example, persons taking part in some clinical trials on a disease that carries a social stigma. It may therefore be crucial to guarantee that the operation of the samples needed to test a statistical hypothesis contains sensitive information about the samples does not align with the objective of the hypothesis, as the latter is about taking samples from the population, rather than the integrity of the sample being taken.

sections.heading: 3 A Simple Upper Bound
sections.text: In this section we provide an upper limit for the problem of differential private identity verification. More generally, we show that if an algorithm requires a dataset of size m for a decision problem, it (ε, 0) -differential private can be made at a multiplicative price of 1 / ε in the sample size. This is a folkloristic result, but we consider and prove it here for completeness. Theorem 2. Assume that there is an algorithm for a decision problem P that is successful with a probability of at least 1 − β and requires a dataset of size m. Then there is a (ε, 0) -differential private algorithm for P that is successful with a probability of at least 45 (1 − β) + 1 / 10 and requires a dataset of size O (m / ε).

sections.heading: 4 Roadblocks to Differentially Private Testing
sections.text: In this section, we describe roadblocks that prevent two natural approaches to differentiated private testing from working. In Section 4.1, we show that if you simply add Laplace noise to the empirical numbers of a dataset (i.e., perform the Laplace mechanism of Theorem 1) and then try to perform an optimal identity tester, the variance of the statistics dramatically increases and thus leads to much greater sample complexity, even in the case of uniformity testing. The intuition behind this phenomenon is this: If we perform uniformity testing in a small sample regime (if the number of samples m is the square root of the domain size n), we will see one (1 − o (1) n element 0 times, O (n) elements 1 times and O (1) elements 2 times. If we add Laplace (10) noise to guarantee (0.1, 0) differential privacy of the domain size n), we will see one (1 − o (1) n element 0 times, O (n) elements 1 times and O (1) elements 2 times. If we add uniformity checks in a small sample regime (if the number of samples m is the square root of the domain size n), we will see one (1 − o) element 0 times, O (n) element 0 times, O (n) element 0 times, O (n) elements 1), and O (1) elements 2 times.

sections.heading: 4.2 A χ2-statistic has high sensitivity
sections.text: Consider the primary statistics we have in Algorithm 1: Z (D) = 1mα2 ∑ i [n] (Ni − mqi) 2 − Ni mqi. As shown in Section 5, it is a natural approach to reduce this statistic to the range [0, 1], to interpret it as probability, and to output the result of Bernoulli (Z) - if p = q, the result will probably be 0, and if dTV (p, q) ≥ α, the result will probably be 1. One might hope that this statistic is of course private. Specifically, we would like the statistic Z to have a low sensitivity and not change much if we take out an individual person. Unfortunately, this is not the case.

sections.heading: 5 Priv’IT: A Differentially Private Identity Tester
6 Experiments
sections.text: All experiments were performed on a laptop computer with a 2.6 GHz Intel Core i7-6700HQ CPU and 8 GB RAM. Significant discussion is required to provide a full comparison with previous work in this area, as the performance of the algorithms varies according to the set of rules. We have compared our algorithm with two current algorithms for different private hypotheses tests: 1. The Monte Carlo goodness of the fit test with Laplace noise from [GLRV16], MCGOF; 2. The projected goodness of the fit tests from [KR17], zCDP-GOF. We have implemented a modified version of Priv'IT, which differs from algorithm 1 in lines 14 to 21. In particular, we consider a statistical Z = i − mqi.
